paragraph: CHAPTER X.
tokens: x

paragraph: After nearly a year's captivity, the King engaged to pay a ransom, and, until the terms could be arranged, his two sons were to be placed as hostages in the hands of the Normans, whilst he returned to his own domains.  The Princes were to be sent to Bayeux; whither Richard had returned, under the charge of the Centevilles, and was now allowed to ride and walk abroad freely, provided he was accompanied by a guard.
tokens: year captivity engage pay ransom term arrange son place hostage hand return own domain send return charge allow ride walk provide accompany guard

paragraph: "I shall rejoice to have Carloman, and make him happy," said Richard; "but I wish Lothaire were not coming."
tokens: rejoice have make happy say wish come

paragraph: "Perhaps," said good Father Lucas, "he comes that you may have a first trial in your father's last lesson, and Abbot Martin's, and return good for evil."
tokens: say good come have first trial father last lesson return good evil

paragraph: The Duke's cheek flushed, and he made no answer.
tokens: cheek flush make answer

paragraph: He and Alberic betook themselves to the watch-tower, and, by and by, saw a cavalcade approaching, with a curtained vehicle in the midst, slung between two horses.  "That cannot be the Princes," said Alberic; "that must surely be some sick lady."
tokens: betak watch tower see cavalcade approach curtain vehicle midst sling horse say sick lady

paragraph: "I only hope it is not the Queen," exclaimed Richard, in dismay.  "But no; Lothaire is such a coward, no doubt he was afraid to ride, and she would not trust her darling without shutting him up like a demoiselle. But come down, Alberic; I will say nothing unkind of Lothaire, if I can help it."
tokens: hope exclaim dismay coward doubt afraid ride trust darling shut demoiselle come say unkind help

paragraph: Richard met the Princes in the court, his sunny hair uncovered, and bowing with such becoming courtesy, that Fru Astrida pressed her son's arm, and bade him say if their little Duke was not the fairest and noblest child in Christendom.
tokens: meet court sunny hair uncover bow such become courtesy press son arm bid say little fair noblest child

paragraph: With black looks, Lothaire stepped from the litter, took no heed of the little Duke, but, roughly calling his attendant, Charlot, to follow him, he marched into the hall, vouchsafing neither word nor look to any as he passed, threw himself into the highest seat, and ordered Charlot to bring him some wine.
tokens: black look step litter take heed little call attendant follow march hall vouchsafe word look pass throw high seat order bring wine

paragraph: Meanwhile, Richard, looking into the litter, saw Carloman crouching in a corner, sobbing with fright.
tokens: look litter see crouch corner sobb fright

paragraph: "Carloman!--dear Carloman!--do not cry.  Come out!  It is I--your own Richard!  Will you not let me welcome you?"
tokens: dear cry come own let welcome

paragraph: Carloman looked, caught at the outstretched hand, and clung to his neck.
tokens: look catch outstretched hand cling neck

paragraph: "Oh, Richard, send us back!  Do not let the savage Danes kill us!"
tokens: send let kill

paragraph: "No one will hurt you.  There are no Danes here.  You are my guest, my friend, my brother.  Look up! here is my own Fru Astrida."
tokens: hurt be guest friend brother look own

paragraph: "But my mother said the Northmen would kill us for keeping you captive. She wept and raved, and the cruel men dragged us away by force.  Oh, let us go back!"
tokens: mother say kill keep captive goot rave cruel man drag force let go

paragraph: "I cannot do that," said Richard; "for you are the King of Denmark's captives, not mine; but I will love you, and you shall have all that is mine, if you will only not cry, dear Carloman.  Oh, Fru Astrida, what shall I do?  You comfort him--" as the poor boy clung sobbing to him.
tokens: do say captive love have cry dear do comfort poor boy cling sobb

paragraph: Fru Astrida advanced to take his hand, speaking in a soothing voice, but he shrank and started with a fresh cry of terror--her tall figure, high cap, and wrinkled face, were to him witch-like, and as she knew no French, he understood not her kind words.  However, he let Richard lead him into the hall, where Lothaire sat moodily in the chair, with one leg tucked under him, and his finger in his mouth.
tokens: advance take hand speak soothing voice shrank start fresh cry terror tall figure high cap wrinkle face witch know understand kind word let lead hall sit chair leg tuck finger mouth

paragraph: "I say, Sir Duke," said he, "is there nothing to be had in this old den of yours?  Not a drop of Bordeaux?"
tokens: say say be have old dan drop

paragraph: Richard tried to repress his anger at this very uncivil way of speaking, and answered, that he thought there was none, but there was plenty of Norman cider.
tokens: try repress anger uncivil way speak answer think be be plenty cider

paragraph: "As if I would taste your mean peasant drinks! I bade them bring my supper--why does it not come?"
tokens: taste mean peasant drink bid bring supper come

paragraph: "Because you are not master here," trembled on Richard's lips, but he forced it back, and answered that it would soon be ready, and Carloman looked imploringly at his brother, and said, "Do not make them angry, Lothaire."
tokens: master tremble lip force answer ready look brother say make angry

paragraph: "What, crying still, foolish child?" said Lothaire.  "Do you not know that if they dare to cross us, my father will treat them as they deserve? Bring supper, I say, and let me have a pasty of ortolans."
tokens: cry foolish child say know dare cross father treat deserve bring supper say let have pasty ortolan

paragraph: "There are none--they are not in season," said Richard.
tokens: be season say

paragraph: "Do you mean to give me nothing I like?  I tell you it shall be the worse for you."
tokens: mean give like tell bad

paragraph: "There is a pullet roasting," began Richard.
tokens: be pullet roasting begin

paragraph: "I tell you, I do not care for pullets--I will have ortolans."
tokens: tell care pullet have ortolan

paragraph: "If I do not take order with that boy, my name is not Eric," muttered the Baron.
tokens: take order boy name mutter

paragraph: "What must he not have made our poor child suffer!" returned Fru Astrida, "but the little one moves my heart.  How small and weakly he is, but it is worth anything to see our little Duke so tender to him."
tokens: make poor child suffer return little one move heart small worth see little tender

paragraph: "He is too brave not to be gentle," said Osmond; and, indeed, the high-spirited, impetuous boy was as soft and kind as a maiden, with that feeble, timid child.  He coaxed him to eat, consoled him, and, instead of laughing at his fears, kept between him and the great bloodhound Hardigras, and drove it off when it came too near.
tokens: brave gentle say high spirit impetuous boy soft kind maiden feeble timid child coax eat console laugh fear keep great bloodhound drive come

paragraph: "Take that dog away," said Lothaire, imperiously.  No one moved to obey him, and the dog, in seeking for scraps, again came towards him.
tokens: take dog say move obey dog seek scrap come

paragraph: "Take it away," he repeated, and struck it with his foot.  The dog growled, and Richard started up in indignation.
tokens: take repeat strike foot dog growl start indignation

paragraph: "Prince Lothaire," he said, "I care not what else you do, but my dogs and my people you shall not maltreat."
tokens: say care do dog person maltreat

paragraph: "I tell you I am Prince!  I do what I will!  Ha! who laughs there?" cried the passionate boy, stamping on the floor.
tokens: tell do laugh cry passionate boy stamp floor

paragraph: "It is not so easy for French Princes to scourge free-born Normans here," said the rough voice of Walter the huntsman: "there is a reckoning for the stripe my Lord Duke bore for me."
tokens: easy french scourge free bear say rough voice huntsman be reckoning stripe bear

paragraph: "Hush, hush, Walter," began Richard; but Lothaire had caught up a footstool, and was aiming it at the huntsman, when his arm was caught.
tokens: begin catch footstool aim huntsman arm catch

paragraph: Osmond, who knew him well enough to be prepared for such outbreaks, held him fast by both hands, in spite of his passionate screams and struggles, which were like those of one frantic.
tokens: know prepare such outbreak hold hand spite passionate scream struggle frantic

paragraph: Sir Eric, meanwhile, thundered forth in his Norman patois, "I would have you to know, young Sir, Prince though you be, you are our prisoner, and shall taste of a dungeon, and bread and water, unless you behave yourself."
tokens: thunder patois have know young prisoner taste dungeon bread water behave

paragraph: Either Lothaire did not hear, or did not believe, and fought more furiously in Osmond's arms, but he had little chance with the stalwart young warrior, and, in spite of Richard's remonstrances, he was carried from the hall, roaring and kicking, and locked up alone in an empty room.
tokens: hear believe fight arm have little chance stalwart young warrior spite remonstrance carry hall roar kick lock empty room

paragraph: "Let him alone for the present," said Sir Eric, putting the Duke aside, "when he knows his master, we shall have peace."
tokens: let present say put know master have peace

paragraph: Here Richard had to turn, to reassure Carloman, who had taken refuge in a dark corner, and there shook like an aspen leaf, crying bitterly, and starting with fright, when Richard touched him.
tokens: have turn reassure take refuge dark corner shake aspen leaf cry start fright touch

paragraph: "Oh, do not put me in the dungeon.  I cannot bear the dark."
tokens: put dungeon bear dark

paragraph: Richard again tried to comfort him, but he did not seem to hear or heed. "Oh! they said you would beat and hurt us for what we did to you! but, indeed, it was not I that burnt your cheek!"
tokens: try comfort seem hear heed say beat hurt do burn cheek

paragraph: "We would not hurt you for worlds, dear Carloman; Lothaire is not in the dungeon--he is only shut up till he is good."
tokens: hurt world dear dungeon shut good

paragraph: "It was Lothaire that did it," repeated Carloman, "and, indeed, you must not be angry with me, for my mother was so cross with me for not having stopped Osmond when I met him with the bundle of straw, that she gave me a blow, that knocked me down.  And were you really there, Richard?"
tokens: do repeat angry mother cross stop meet bundle straw give blow knock

paragraph: Richard told his story, and was glad to find Carloman could smile at it; and then Fru Astrida advised him to take his little friend to bed. Carloman would not lie down without still holding Richard's hand, and the little Duke spared no pains to set him at rest, knowing what it was to be a desolate captive far from home.
tokens: tell story glad find smile advise take little friend bed lie hold hand little spare pain set rest know desolate captive home

paragraph: "I thought you would be good to me," said Carloman.  "As to Lothaire, it serves him right, that you should use him as he used you."
tokens: think good say serve right use use

paragraph: "Oh, no, Carloman; if I had a brother I would never speak so of him."
tokens: have brother speak

paragraph: "But Lothaire is so unkind."
tokens: unkind

paragraph: "Ah! but we must be kind to those who are unkind to us."
tokens: kind unkind

paragraph: The child rose on his elbow, and looked into Richard's face.  "No one ever told me so before."
tokens: child rise elbow look face tell

paragraph: "Oh, Carloman, not Brother Hilary?"
tokens: brother

paragraph: "I never heed Brother Hilary--he is so lengthy, and wearisome; besides, no one is ever kind to those that hate them."
tokens: heed lengthy wearisome kind hate

paragraph: "My father was," said Richard.
tokens: father say

paragraph: "And they killed him!" said Carloman.
tokens: kill say

paragraph: "Yes," said Richard, crossing himself, "but he is gone to be in peace."
tokens: say cross gone peace

paragraph: "I wonder if it is happier there, than here," said Carloman.  "I am not happy.  But tell me why should we be good to those that hate us?"
tokens: wonder happy say happy tell good hate

paragraph: "Because the holy Saints were--and look at the Crucifix, Carloman.  That was for them that hated Him.  And, don't you know what our Pater Noster says?"
tokens: holy look hate know say

paragraph: Poor little Carloman could only repeat the Lord's Prayer in Latin--he had not the least notion of its meaning--in which Richard had been carefully instructed by Father Lucas.  He began to explain it, but before many words had passed his lips, little Carloman was asleep.
tokens: poor little repeat have least notion meaning instruct begin explain many word pass lip little asleep

paragraph: The Duke crept softly away to beg to be allowed to go to Lothaire; he entered the room, already dark, with a pine torch in his hand, that so flickered in the wind, that he could at first see nothing, but presently beheld a dark lump on the floor.
tokens: creep beg allow go enter room dark pine torch hand flicker wind see beheld dark lump floor

paragraph: "Prince Lothaire," he said, "here is--"
tokens: say

paragraph: Lothaire cut him short.  "Get away," he said.  "If it is your turn now, it will be mine by and by.  I wish my mother had kept her word, and put your eyes out."
tokens: cut short get say turn wish mother keep word put eye

paragraph: Richard's temper did not serve for such a reply.  "It is a foul shame of you to speak so, when I only came out of kindness to you--so I shall leave you here all night, and not ask Sir Eric to let you out."
tokens: temper serve reply foul shame speak come kindness leave night ask let

paragraph: And he swung back the heavy door with a resounding clang.  But his heart smote him when he told his beads, and remembered what he had said to Carloman.  He knew he could not sleep in his warm bed when Lothaire was in that cold gusty room.  To be sure, Sir Eric said it would do him good, but Sir Eric little knew how tender the French Princes were.
tokens: swing heavy door resounding clang heart smeat tell bead remember say know sleep warm bed cold gusty room sure say do good know tender french

paragraph: So Richard crept down in the dark, slid back the bolt, and called, "Prince, Prince, I am sorry I was angry.  Come out, and let us try to be friends."
tokens: creep dark slide bolt call sorry angry come let try friend

paragraph: "What do you mean?" said Lothaire.
tokens: mean say

paragraph: "Come out of the cold and dark.  Here am I.  I will show you the way. Where is your hand?  Oh, how cold it is.  Let me lead you down to the hall fire."
tokens: come cold dark show way hand cold let lead hall fire

paragraph: Lothaire was subdued by fright, cold, and darkness, and quietly allowed Richard to lead him down.  Round the fire, at the lower end of the hall, snored half-a-dozen men-at-arms; at the upper hearth there was only Hardigras, who raised his head as the boys came in.  Richard's whisper and soft pat quieted him instantly, and the two little Princes sat on the hearth together, Lothaire surprised, but sullen.  Richard stirred the embers, so as to bring out more heat, then spoke: "Prince, will you let us be friends?"
tokens: subdued fright cold darkness allow lead fire low end hall snore half man arm upper hearth be raise head boy come whisper soft pat quiet little sit hearth surprise sullen stirr ember bring more heat speak let friend

paragraph: "I must, if I am in your power."
tokens: power

paragraph: "I wish you would be my guest and comrade."
tokens: wish guest comrade

paragraph: "Well, I will; I can't help it."
tokens: help

paragraph: Richard thought his advances might have been more graciously met, and, having little encouragement to say more, took Lothaire to bed, as soon as he was warm.
tokens: think advance meet have little encouragement say more take bed warm
